Violation_Type: Procedural Unfairness due to Incompetent Representation
Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration consultant's incompetence resulted in a breach of procedural fairness affecting the H&C application outcome
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 25(1)
Application_Facts: Omission of key evidence: relationship with deceased son, daughter’s refugee claim, grandchildren's best interests, and medical conditions
Decision_Outcome: Case remitted to CIC for redetermination with additional information
Court_Ruling: Procedural fairness was breached due to consultant's negligence; tripartite test for incompetence met
Defendant_Behavior: Failure to include critical evidence in the H&C application
Grounds_for_Claim: Negligence by immigration consultant leading to prejudicial omissions
Legal_Standard: Tripartite test for incompetent representation: specific negligence, evidentiary support, and likelihood of altered outcome
Assessment_Factor: Impact of omitted evidence on the strength of the H&C application
Evidence_Assessed: Omitted evidence that could have strengthened the H&C application
Relief_Sought: Remittal to CIC for reconsideration with new evidence
Governing_Rule: Competent representation required under procedural fairness; negligence must be material
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to submit relevant personal and familial circumstances
Harm_Assessment: Prejudice to the applicant due to weakened application from omissions
Cause_Description: Omissions in the H&C application due to alleged consultant incompetence
Evidence_Handling: Key evidence not submitted due to consultant error
Evidence_Assessment: Omissions were significant and likely affected decision outcome
Decision_Rationale: Inclusion of omitted evidence could reasonably have led to a different result
Evidentiary_Issues: Critical evidence excluded due to consultant negligence
